author: By Erik Piepenburg
title: Five Horror Movies to Stream Now
description: This month’s picks will take you on a global tour of terror, with tales of a Taiwanese gay ghost and a Norwegian canine whose owner is a dog’s worst friend.
content: There’s nothing remotely terrifying in this charming opposites-attract ghost comedy, a box office hit in Taiwan. Give it a shot if your taste in scary movies is the flavor of Horror Lite with a side of screwball romantic (ish) comedy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Nolan
title: 1-Year-Old Dies and 3 Children Are Hospitalized in Day Care Emergency
description: An investigation was underway, but the circumstances remained unclear.
content: A 1-year-old boy died on Friday and three other children at a Bronx day care were hospitalized under circumstances that were under investigation, officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Begala
title: Lawrence Wright’s Rollicking Satire of Texas Politics
description: A rancher turned hero finds himself elected to the Statehouse in the novel “Mr. Texas.”
content: “Built for giants, inhabited by pygmies.” That’s what the legendary Texas politician Bob Eckhardt used to tell awe-struck visitors about the Texas Capitol. The Goddess of Liberty, who stands atop Austin’s dome, peers down 302 feet at the mortals below, 14 feet higher than the U.S. Capitol.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Floods in Libya
description: What is your reaction to this image?
content: Torrential rain from a storm that swept across the Mediterranean Sea over the weekend caused two dams to burst near Derna, a coastal city in the North African nation of Libya, killing thousands and washing entire neighborhoods out to sea. At least 10,000 more people were estimated to be missing and 30,000 to have been displaced.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Oussama Zahr
title: Lise Davidsen Shows Her Vocal and Theatrical Power in Recital Debut
description: Davidsen, a true dramatic soprano, was the rare singer whose first New York recital came at the Metropolitan Opera House.
content: When Lise Davidsen sang the first four notes of Elisabeth’s aria “Dich, teure Halle,” from Wagner’s “Tannhäuser,” at the Metropolitan Opera last night, all I could think to write down in my notebook was “holy” — and remembering to mind my manners — “cow.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: The Autoworkers Go on Strike
description: The action by the United Auto Workers is part of a burst of labor activism attempting to reverse a decades-long trend.
content: Tumultuous labor strikes are a natural part of an economy with an expanding middle class.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: Biden Sides With the Autoworkers
description: Also, a look at post-pandemic fashion. Here’s the latest at the end of Friday.
content: For the first time in its nearly nine-decade history, the United Auto Workers staged a strike today against all three of the major U.S. automakers. Thousands of union workers, whose contracts expired at midnight, walked off the job at factories run by General Motors, Ford and Chrysler (now owned by Stellantis).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonah E. Bromwich, Ben Protess and Alan Feuer
title: Trump Lawsuit Against Judge Could Delay N.Y. Fraud Trial
description: The delay came as federal prosecutors pushed back against the former president’s efforts to attack another judge in his election interference case in Washington.
content: Donald J. Trump has sued the judge overseeing the New York attorney general’s civil fraud case against him, a move that could delay his upcoming trial.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Should Aging Leaders Step Aside?
description: Readers discuss Mitt Romney, President Biden, Donald Trump, Nancy Pelosi and others. Also: Hunter Biden’s indictment; seniors and technology.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Chaundler
title: Spain’s Women’s Team Demands Full Reorganization of National Federation
description: The players’ demands came on a day that a restraining order was granted against Luis Rubiales, the former head of the federation, who forcibly kissed a star forward, Jennifer Hermoso.
content: Shortly before the roster was due to be announced for the Spanish women’s first international soccer match since their World Cup victory, the Royal Spanish Football Federation postponed the event until further notice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tiffany Martinbrough and Michelle V. Agins
title: When the Wig Is a Character: Backstage at Jocelyn Bioh’s New Play
description: The styles in “Jaja’s African Hair Braiding,” in previews on Broadway, require a wig designer, several braiders, some synthetic hair and lots of patience.
content: Known for her amusing scripts and plaited hairstyles, Jocelyn Bioh can count only three times when she was without braids. “There’s a real freedom in getting your braids done,” she said. “Then you don’t have to worry about your hair for the next few weeks.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Golembiewski
title: Some Whales May Have Been Wiped Out by Medieval Europeans
description: A study of hundreds of specimens from European archaeological digs found two species of whales that are no longer present in the continent’s waters.
content: Industrial-scale whaling in the 19th and 20th centuries nearly drove many whale species into extinction. Populations of some of the large marine mammals are just starting to recover after the kind of predation described in the novel “Moby-Dick,” while others face ongoing peril to their existence. But it turns out that whaling’s effects on where whales live go back much deeper into human history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariq Panja
title: FIFA Delays Have Cities Worried About 2026 World Cup Plans
description: With about 1,000 days until the opening game of soccer’s showcase event, U.S. organizers are waiting for answers, and action, from the sport’s governing body.
content: When FIFA announced several years ago that it would take the preparations for soccer’s 2026 World Cup in-house, it argued the change would streamline the planning for a sprawling championship that would be larger and more complex and require greater expertise than ever before. That the change would also grant FIFA greater control over the $11 billion in revenue it expects from its biggest cash cow was perhaps even more important.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stacy Cowley
title: Former Wells Fargo Executive Avoids Prison in Sham Accounts Scandal
description: Prosecutors had sought a year of incarceration, which they said would be a deterrent to other corporate executives.
content: A former top Wells Fargo executive avoided prison time for her role in the bank’s sham accounts scandal, after a federal judge on Friday instead sentenced her to six months of home confinement and three years of probation. She was also ordered to pay a $100,000 fine and perform 120 hours of community service.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes
title: Studios Say Talks With Striking Writers May Resume Next Week
description: The Alliance of Motion Picture and Television Producers said the union had asked for a meeting, which would be the first in nearly a month.
content: Contract negotiations between Hollywood studios and striking screenwriters could restart next week, the studios said in a statement on Thursday. A return to bargaining — the last talks were held three weeks ago — could be a turning point in the strike, now in its fifth month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Variety: Viral Trigrams
description: Test your solving immunity on this John Suarez poser, from the 183rd National Puzzlers’ League Convention.
content: VIRAL TRIGRAMS — Every year The Times runs a puzzle from the National Puzzlers’ League Convention, which this year was held in Montreal in July. This treat from John Suarez is our second iteration of Trigrams; the first example is from 2019 and has slightly different rules. The key component in both puzzles is groups of three letters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ed O'Loughlin
title: Ireland’s Latest Fiscal Headache: What to Do With 10 Billion Euros
description: The government in Dublin has a big budget surplus, thanks to a boom in tax revenue from multinational companies. Build more housing? Or a subway? Sock it away? Whatever the case, someone will be unhappy.
content: Fifteen years after a collapsed housing bubble forced Ireland to borrow tens of billions of dollars or risk going bust, the country is discovering that having too much money can also be a problem.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Satariano
title: TikTok Fined $370 Million for Mishandling Child Data
description: The data-collection practices of TikTok that were cited by the European Union are becoming a common target for global regulators.
content: TikTok was fined roughly $370 million on Friday by European Union regulators for having weak safeguards to protect the personal information of children using the platform, a sign of increased scrutiny facing the social media service.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Buckley and Julian E. Barnes
title: China Is Investigating Its Defense Minister, U.S. Officials Say
description: General Li Shangfu’s recent absence from the public eye, which follows the removal of two top commanders, has raised questions about Xi Jinping’s confidence in his military.
content: China’s defense minister, Gen. Li Shangfu, has been placed under investigation, according to two U.S. officials, fueling speculation about further upheaval in the military after the abrupt removal of two top commanders in charge of the country’s nuclear force.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Paton
title: Vogue World Comes to London
description: A starry night orchestrated by Anna Wintour kicked off the city’s fashion week.
content: At Royal Theatre Drury Lane, a full house had taken their seats at the behest of the voice of God, who happened to be Sir Ian McKellen. Onstage, a giant projection of Big Ben struck 8 p.m. — where the dials remained for another 12 minutes. The audience wasn’t surprised: Fashion shows always start late.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: Chicken Karaage, Pizza Salad and a Golden Knot of Challah
description: The weekend is a perfect time to experiment with new flavors and techniques, to bring the delicious into your life and the lives of those around you.
content: Good morning. I roasted a pig in a box, as I realize I’ve been doing for close to 20 years. I had a perfect Coke float with vanilla ice cream, in a tall paper cup with a long spoon and a wide straw. I cooked without recipes — elegant salads built on rounds of late-summer tomatoes, chopped cheese quesadillas, Boston mackerel crudo — and I read a ton of books. There was fishing most days, adventures in the woods, plenty of naps. The rough-winged swallow babies across the way left the nest, learned to feed themselves and departed for Florida with their parents.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katrina Miller
title: A Fireball Whacked Into Jupiter, and Astronomers Got It on Video
description: In August, stargazers in Japan recorded a bright flash on the giant gas planet. Scientists want to use data like this to study our solar system’s birth.
content: Ko Arimatsu, an astronomer at Kyoto University in Japan, received an intriguing email a couple of weeks ago: An amateur astronomer in his country had spotted a bright flash in Jupiter’s atmosphere.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anushka Patil
title: The U.S. ambassador visits Evan Gershkovich, a WSJ reporter detained in Russia.
description: ‘He remains strong and is keeping up with the news,’ the American diplomat said.
content: The U.S. ambassador to Russia met Friday with Evan Gershkovich, the Wall Street Journal reporter jailed in Moscow, a few days after his family appealed to the United Nations for help in bringing him home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ellie Duke and Sutton Lynch
title: Whales, From Above
description: The photographer Sutton Lynch is documenting a dramatic turning point off the coast of Long Island — a resurgence of sea life after decades of depletion.
content: Sutton Lynch rises most days before the sun, arriving at Atlantic Beach in Amagansett, N.Y., for the early-morning calm. It’s the same beach he’s been going to since he was a child, and where he worked as a lifeguard for years as a teenager. Now 23, he spends his mornings surveying the horizon. When he spots activity on the water’s surface, he sends out his drone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jancee Dunn
title: Want to Thrive? First, Learn to Fail.
description: Mistakes are inevitable, but we should embrace them, experts say.
content: When Sara Blakely, founder of the shapewear brand Spanx, was a child, her father would pose an unusual question to her and her brother over dinner: How did you fail this week?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily LaBarge
title: Life Lessons From the Bloomsbury Group’s Wardrobe
description: An exhibition about the bohemian set’s “philosophy of fashion” goes deeper than just clothes.
content: Every few years, a new cultural product — book, film, TV show, opera, ballet — emerges about the Bloomsbury Group, the early-20th century affiliation of artists, writers and thinkers that got its name from the central London neighborhood known for its garden squares.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Victor and Neal E. Boudette
title: U.A.W. Begins Strike at GM, Ford and Stellantis Plants. Here’s What to Know
description: The strike began on Friday morning at three plants, but could expand if contract talks remain bogged down.
content: Negotiators for the United Auto Workers union and the three large U.S. automakers — General Motors, Ford Motor and Stellantis, the parent of Chrysler, Jeep and Ram — remained far apart as a limited strike began on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenna Russell, Alicia Anstead and Colleen Cronin
title: In Coastal New England, a Matter-of-Fact Girding for Hurricane Lee
description: People in Maine and Massachusetts, accustomed to powerful nor’easters if not hurricanes, dutifully prepared but appeared largely unfazed by the foul weather to come.
content: As Hurricane Lee churned closer to coastal New England on Friday, with winds expected to intensify overnight, cruise ships sought refuge in Portland, Maine, and homeowners in Provincetown, Mass., piled sandbags.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Saif Hasnat and Mujib Mashal
title: Bangladesh Sentences Prominent Human Rights Activists to Prison
description: The jail time in response to a report the government said spread misinformation stirs alarm about the nation’s deepening political repression.
content: Two prominent human rights activists who have tracked extrajudicial killings and disappearances in Bangladesh were sentenced on Thursday to two years in prison, raising alarm about a new escalation in quashing dissent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erica L. Green and Abbie VanSickle
title: Justice Ketanji Brown Jackson Calls on Nation to Remember Ugly Past Truths
description: She was the keynote speaker at the 60th anniversary of the Ku Klux Klan bombing that killed four young girls at the Sixteenth Street Baptist Church in Birmingham, Ala.
content: Supreme Court Justice Ketanji Brown Jackson on Friday called on the nation to accept some of the ugliest truths in its history as she confronted the debates roiling the country about racism and violence against Black Americans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrey Henkin
title: Charles Gayle, Saxophonist of Fire and Brimstone, Dies at 84
description: An intense and uncompromising player, he made music that one critic said was more about “motion and spirit” than tonal centers, rhythms and melodies.
content: Charles Gayle, an uncompromising saxophonist who spent years living and performing on the streets of New York before beginning a recording career when he was nearly 50, died on Sept. 5 in Brooklyn. He was 84.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: Selling Saudi Soccer, One Like at a Time
description: The standard of play in the Saudi Pro League doesn’t matter when no one’s watching the games.
content: Neymar’s endorsement was not, perhaps, the most ringing. Back in Brazil to play for his national team this month, he had been asked — not for the first time — to address the lingering suspicion that, in leaving Paris St.-Germain for Saudi Arabia and Al-Hilal, one of the finest players of his generation might not have chosen the most challenging coda to his career.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elda Cantú and Joe Coscarelli
title: After Threats in Mexico, Peso Pluma Postpones U.S. Concerts
description: The breakout musician has not given a reason for rescheduling the dates. The authorities in Mexico are investigating the credibility of written threats against him.
content: A string of concerts in the United States by the breakout Mexican singer-songwriter Peso Pluma were postponed this week after written threats were apparently issued by a major drug cartel. The authorities said they were investigating the credibility of the threats, which were written on banners and posted publicly in the border city Tijuana.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Madison Malone Kircher
title: Beware the TikTok Eavesdroppers
description: Strangers’ conversations should not be content.
content: Close your eyes and imagine the last gossipy conversation you had with a friend in a public setting. Maybe you were complaining about your spouse over a cappuccino in your neighborhood coffee shop. Or loudly talking over the din of the subway about your boss. You love your spouse, and genuinely like your boss, but you just needed to vent a little. Who among us, right?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. David Goodman
title: Texas Senators Begin to Deliberate Paxton Impeachment
description: The Republican-controlled Senate is weighing whether to remove the attorney general, Ken Paxton, based on evidence of bribery and abuse of office.
content: Deliberations began on Friday in the impeachment trial of Ken Paxton, the Texas attorney general, as the jury of state senators weighed allegations of bribery and abuse of office based on complaints made against him by his most senior former aides.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Santul Nerkar
title: Union Push by Dartmouth Athletes Is Distinct From Previous Failed Efforts
description: A bid to unionize by the Dartmouth men’s basketball team raises questions that earlier unsuccessful campaigns in college sports have not addressed.
content: When the Dartmouth College men’s basketball team filed a petition to unionize this week, it was a reminder of how much the movement for player empowerment has grown in college sports.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Friday Briefing
description: Ukrainian attacks on Russian-occupied Crimea.
content: Ukraine launched several new long-distance attacks on targets in Russia-occupied Crimea and the Black Sea, seeking to break down the Kremlin’s war effort with strikes far beyond the front lines. Russia illegally annexed the Crimean Peninsula in 2014.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David French and Vishakha Darbha
title: The Anti-Abortion Movement Won the Legal Battle, but It’s Losing the War
description: Columnist David French argues the politics of division comes at a cost.
content: The abortion rate in America has steadily increased since 2016, despite the 2022 Supreme Court decision overturning the constitutional right to abortion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Bradley
title: Millions Saw His Paintings on TV. In the Art World, His Work Still Went Unnoticed.
description: In his lifetime, Ernie Barnes was largely dismissed and ignored by the industry. He became an icon anyway.
content: IN THE 1970S, buying a print of Ernie Barnes’s “The Sugar Shack,” the iconic 1976 dance club painting that adorns the cover of Marvin Gaye’s album released that spring, “I Want You,” and appears in the credits for the classic sitcom “Good Times” (1974-79), required nothing more than mailing a $20 check to the artist’s West Hollywood studio. In 2022, the second of two originals — inspired by a childhood adventure of sneaking into a famed dance hall to watch couples drag and sway to the live performances of Clyde McPhatter or Duke Ellington — came up for auction at Christie’s, selling for $15.3 million. The buyer was the Houston-based energy trader and high-stakes gambler Bill Perkins, 54, who won a bidding war against 22 other prospects. This vast divergence of price belies a convergence of spirit: The countless individuals hanging inexpensive prints on the walls of bedrooms and barbershops share with Perkins (and no doubt with the other wealthy collectors who bid the painting up to more than 76 times its high estimate) an ineluctable desire for the nostalgia and affirmation that Barnes’s work conveys.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Monika Pronczuk
title: Men Sentenced to Life in Prison for 2016 Brussels Bombings
description: Three men, including one who is presumed dead, were sentenced to life in prison. The sentences arrived seven years after the deadliest terrorist assault in Belgium’s history.
content: A jury in a Belgian criminal court sentenced seven men responsible for organizing a series of bombings in Brussels in March 2016 on Friday to prison terms ranging from 10 years to life. The sentences arrived seven years after the deadliest terrorist assault in Belgium’s history, which ruptured a multicultural society and sent shock waves across Europe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: The Weekender
description: How Mattel made “Barbie” a cinematic hit. Also: an interview with Sean Combs, and sharks living on a golf course.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Cameron
title: We Thought We Were Saving the Planet, but We Were Planting a Time Bomb
description: I spent a summer putting trees into the ground. Thirty years later, I watched my youthful idealism literally go up in smoke.
content: At first, it looked like a sunset. It was just after five o’clock in June. I was running in Toronto beside Lake Ontario when I stopped to glance at my watch and noticed that the sky was no longer blue but a rusted orange. It took only a few breaths to realize the bonfire smell in the air was the drifting product of faraway wildfires.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Calum Marsh
title: The Many Mustaches of Kenneth Branagh’s Hercule Poirot
description: In “A Haunting in Venice,” the facial hair is practically a character, and it evolves as needed, thanks to the designer who considers it “a friend.”
content: After a long day on the set of “A Haunting in Venice,” the latest Kenneth Branagh murder-mystery based on Agatha Christie’s Hercule Poirot stories, the hair and makeup designer Wakana Yoshihara would leave the crew, find a quiet space and sit down with the detective’s prodigious mustache, a sweeping half-moon of lush gray hair and attendant soul patch.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Elon Musk and Naomi Klein Are Complicated
description: Our critic Jennifer Szalai discusses Walter Isaacson’s biography of the billionaire entrepreneur along with her recent profile of Klein, the Canadian writer and activist.
content: Elon Musk, the billionaire South Africa-born entrepreneur whose business interests include the electric car company Tesla, the private rocket company SpaceX and the social media platform X (formerly Twitter), is the richest person in the world — and the subject of an expansive new biography by Walter Isaacson, whose earlier subjects famously include the Apple founder Steve Jobs. Our critic Jennifer Szalai reviewed the Musk biography for The Times, and on the podcast this week she tells the host Gilbert Cruz that at several points in the book Isaacson circles back to Jobs, for good reason.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Goldberg
title: Mitt Romney’s Tragic Ambivalence
description: His party is a threat and he should say so.
content: Rolling out the announcement that he won’t run for re-election, Senator Mitt Romney of Utah has framed it as a passing of the torch. “At the end of another term, I’d be in my mid-80s,” he said in a video statement. “Frankly it’s time for a new generation of leaders. They’re the ones that need to make the decisions that will shape the world they will be living in.” He clearly means this as a rebuke to the 80-year-old Joe Biden and the 77-year-old Donald Trump, neither of whom, he said, “are leading their party” to confront the major issues facing our country. “The next generation of leaders must take America to the next stage of global leadership.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: FRIDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soraya Roberts
title: Actors Seeking Stability Turn to Directing at the Toronto Festival
description: Movies directed by actors were prominent at this year’s Toronto International Film Festival. Could the reasons they’re striking also underlie the career move?
content: By my count, there are 10 movies by actor-turned-directors at this year’s Toronto International Film Festival. Ten. The majority, including Chris Pine’s “Poolman” and Anna Kendrick’s “Woman of the Hour,” are debuts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: What Does a Good Economy Look Like?
description: Putting President Biden’s record in context.
content: In the past couple of weeks, I’ve written one column arguing that the economic situation for working class America is now better, relative to a decade ago, than some pessimistic populists make it sound, and another arguing that the eating-away at American wages because of inflation explains some important measure of President Biden’s political difficulties.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Jewett
title: Why the F.D.A. Took So Long to Tackle a Disputed Cold Remedy
description: Pharmacists affiliated with the University of Florida have spent decades nudging the agency to pull a decongestant from over-the-counter medicines.
content: Dr. Leslie Hendeles began prodding the Food and Drug Administration to reject a decongestant in cold medicines when he had a mop of curly red hair and Bill Clinton had just become president.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tammy LaGorce
title: How Two Game Lovers Conspired to See Each Other Again
description: Morgan Hoit and Dylan Pager, who met at work seven years ago, enlisted their roommates in organizing a game night. The hangout went so well that the two deleted their dating apps.
content: When Dylan Pager first met Morgan Landfair Hoit at work in November 2016, he thought she was cute. Ms. Hoit, a new graduate of Duke, had just started her job in the theater industry, and the assistant she was replacing brought her to the management office to meet her new colleagues. “It didn’t cross my mind to mix work and dating,” Mr. Pager said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Swan, Charlie Savage and Maggie Haberman
title: Biden Administration Aims to Trump-Proof the Federal Work Force
description: If Donald Trump wins a second term, he and his allies want to revive a plan to allow a president to fire civil service workers who are supposed to be hired on merit. The Biden administration is trying to thwart it.
content: When President Biden took office, he swiftly canceled an executive order his predecessor Donald J. Trump had issued that could have enabled Mr. Trump to fire tens of thousands of federal workers and replace them with loyalists. But Democrats never succeeded in enacting legislation to strengthen protections for the civil service system as a matter of law.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Hale
title: ‘The Changeling’ Review: Bye Bye Baby
description: LaKeith Stanfield stars in a dark modern fairy tale about a father who doesn’t listen when his wife has doubts about who (or what) is in the crib.
content: A changeling is what a fairy or demon or troll leaves behind when it kidnaps a human baby. Take your eye off your newborn for just a second and you might find yourself raising a ravenous little monster that is not the one you gave birth to.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. Edward Moreno
title: A rise in car prices would hit consumers already facing higher payments.
description: If the U.A.W. strike lasts long enough, it could cut the supply of vehicles and push prices even higher.
content: It’s not a great time to be in the market for a new car.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Iverson
title: Easy Mode: Clues for Sept. 15
description: Get some help on the Friday crossword puzzle.
content: Friday crosswords are among the hardest of the week. They are themeless, which means you can’t rely on that extra level of context to solve the puzzle, and the clues are written with a higher level of wit and wordplay. We know this can be daunting for newer solvers. If you need a little hint to unlock the puzzle, we’ve provided easy clues you can use. We recommend ctrl + f the number of the clue you’re looking for. You can also play a digital version of this puzzle with easy clues by signing up for our Easy Mode newsletter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Audra D. S. Burch
title: The Trials of Aurora: A Colorado City’s Deep Divide Over Policing
description: After Elijah McClain died in 2019, the case seemed to be closed. The George Floyd protests — and the backlash to them — would change everything.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melinda Wenner Moyer
title: Does Vitamin C Actually Help Your Skin?
description: Here’s what dermatologists say about this trendy ingredient.
content: If you’ve spent time exploring the skin care side of TikTok, you know that dermatologists love to tout the benefits of vitamin C serums and creams. They claim the vitamin can brighten and firm the skin, protect it from sun and environmental damage, diminish dark spots and even reduce the signs of aging.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic
title: As Joe Jonas and Sophie Turner Split, It’s Time to Spin
description: When famous people divorce, it’s not just an unraveling relationship. It’s a public relations dance. Even when it’s “amicable.”
content: When Joe Jonas and Sophie Turner announced their divorce on Instagram, the joint statement they released seemed relatively tame in the world of celebrity splits.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: A Podcast That Sounds the Alarm on the American Dream
description: In its third season, “The Dream” trains its gimlet eye on the big business of life coaching, with a twist.
content: On a spring morning in Los Angeles, the podcaster Jane Marie stepped out onto the patio at the back of her rental home in Silver Lake for the first workout with her newly hired life coach, Jessie Monroy. An upbeat drill sergeant in glitter nail polish, Monroy put Marie through a routine of squats, planks and push-ups.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage, Maggie Haberman and Jonathan Swan
title: How Biden’s View on Presidential War Powers Has Shifted
description: The president says he can direct limited military operations without lawmakers’ approval. Most G.O.P. presidential candidates, including Donald J. Trump, did not answer a survey on executive power.
content: If he is elected to a second term, President Biden pledged that he will go to Congress to start any major war but said he believed he was empowered “to direct limited U.S. military operations abroad” without such approval when such strikes served critical American interests.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neal E. Boudette
title: U.A.W. Goes on Strike Against Detroit’s Big 3 Automakers
description: Workers walked off the job at 3 initial sites in a targeted labor action against Ford, General Motors and Stellantis — the first ever of all three at once.
content: Thousands of members of the United Automobile Workers union went on strike Friday at three plants in three Midwestern states in what was the first strike simultaneously affecting all three Detroit automakers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Kinzer
title: Fernando Botero, Artist of Whimsical Rotundity, Is Dead at 91
description: His voluptuous figures, both in paintings and in sculpture, portrayed the high and mighty as well as everyday people through an enlarging prism.
content: Fernando Botero, the Colombian whose voluptuous pictures and sculptures of overstuffed generals, bishops, prostitutes, housewives and other products of his whimsical imagination made him one of the world’s best-known artists, died on Friday in Monaco. He was 91.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Fahy and Raúl Vilchis
title: Suing. Heckling. Cursing. N.Y.C. Protests Against Migrants Escalate
description: After migrants were sheltered at a defunct school, neighbors on Staten Island turned on a loudspeaker and put up signs to drive them away.
content: The loudspeaker on a quiet Staten Island street blasted demands at 117 decibels, louder than a dog barking in your ear. Pointed at a school that is sheltering some of the 110,000 migrants who have arrived in New York City over the last year and a half, the message could not have been more unwelcoming: “Immigrants are not safe here.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: Love Letters to California
description: Readers share why they adore living in the Golden State.
content: Over Labor Day weekend, I visited for the first time Lassen Volcanic National Park, a gem in the mountains in northeastern California.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher and Chris Cameron
title: Facing Off in Washington, DeSantis Tries to Shake Trump’s Hold on Christian Right
description: During dueling appearances, Gov. Ron DeSantis cast himself as a warrior for the religious right, while the former president used familiar attack lines against his rival.
content: Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida and former President Donald J. Trump clashed on Friday before two crowds of social conservatives in Washington, with dueling speeches that demonstrated just how influential evangelical voters are expected to be in the presidential primary.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Roy
title: A Quirky Auction to Support Crew Members Affected By the Writers Strike
description: Lena Dunham will paint a mural in your home. Adam Scott will walk your dog. Natasha Lyonne will help you finish the Sunday crossword.
content: A typical Hollywood charity auction, like the Baby2Baby Gala, might consist of beauty sessions with sought-after dermatologists, autographed books and set memorabilia, and the occasional five-minute photo op. It might also be closed to the public, available only to those connected individuals who can afford to bid richly.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: An Arts Center Opens at Ground Zero With Stars, Onstage and Off
description: The Perelman Performing Arts Center opened Thursday with performances by Cynthia Erivo, Tiler Peck, Tariq Trotter, Angélique Kidjo and James Taylor.
content: Cynthia Erivo sang “(You Make Me Feel Like) A Natural Woman.” The ballerina Tiler Peck moonwalked, on pointe shoes, to a rap by Tariq Trotter. The countertenor Anthony Roth Costanzo performed both parts of a duet from Mozart’s “The Marriage of Figaro,” twirling from stage left to stage right with each character change.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Romy Madley Croft’s Solo Debut and More: The Week in Reporter Reads
description: Articles from around The Times, narrated just for you.
content: This weekend, listen to a collection of articles from around The New York Times, read aloud by the reporters who wrote them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ann Carrns
title: Beware Companies Selling Credit ‘Repair’ Services
description: Consumers have a right to dispute mistakes on their credit reports. But if they’ve made late payments, that can’t be erased, consumer experts say.
content: Anyone whose credit score has been marred by late payments or financial stumbles can understand the allure of a quick fix that scrubs tarnished credit. But beware the companies that sell credit “repair” services over the phone and charge fees upfront.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carlotta Gall
title: ‘We Are Accidentally Alive’: A Muslim Cleric Reflects on His War Experience
description: Said Ismahilov fled Russians in eastern Ukraine and then fled the suburb of Bucha when the war began. Once the mufti of Ukraine, he is now a medic on the front line.
content: An activist Muslim cleric in Ukraine with an arrest warrant over his head, Said Ismahilov had no doubt of the danger as Russian troops advanced on the capital, Kyiv, at the start of the war last year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Roose, Casey Newton, Davis Land, Rachel Cohn, Jen Poyant, Alyssa Moxley, Dan Powell, Elisheba Ittoop, Marion Lozano and Sophia Lanman
title: Casey v. Kevin on U.S. v. Google + Walter Isaacson on Two Years With Elon Musk
description: It’s been a bumpy ride for the most important players in tech.
content: Is Google allowed to spend billions of dollars to make its search product the default browser? That is the question at the center of U.S. et al. v. Google — the most important tech trial of the modern internet era — and Kevin and Casey disagree on the answer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roger Cohen
title: Muslim Students’ Robes Are Latest Fault Line for French Identity
description: When the French education minister declared that the abayas favored by some Muslim women “can no longer be worn in schools,” he stoked a fierce debate over the country’s secular ideals.
content: The mass French return to work, known as the “rentrée,” is often marked by renewed social conflict. This year has been no exception as the summer lull has given way to yet another battle over a recurrent national obsession: How Muslim women should dress.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: Biden’s Tough Week: The President Faces Personal and Political Setbacks
description: In the past seven days, President Biden was targeted for impeachment and his son was indicted. That was just the start.
content: It says something about the way things have been going for President Biden lately that being targeted for impeachment was not the worst news of a tough week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alastair Macaulay
title: Erik Aschengreen, 88, Dies; Historian and Critic Illuminated Danish Dance
description: In books, articles and lectures across Europe and America, he broadened an international appreciation of his native country’s rich dance tradition.
content: Erik Aschengreen, an eminent dance critic and scholar who did much to show the international importance and history of Danish ballet while also exploring aspects of French, American and other dance traditions, died on Sept. 9 in Copenhagen. He was 88.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frid
title: Why Might a Parisian Wine Bar and Ice Cream Parlor Hire a Bouncer?
description: This summer, the owners of the wine and ice cream bar Folderol took a number of measures to manage crowds after their small business experienced an unsolicited wave of TikTok fame.
content: “They don’t even taste the ice cream,” Jessica Yang said of the social-media-conscious crowd that descended this summer on Folderol, a natural wine bar and artisanal ice cream parlor in Paris that she owns and operates with her husband, Robert Compagnon. “They just let it pool into a bowl of melting liquid and die in the sun.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zoey Poll
title: The Make-Do Joys of Terrazzo
description: Modern artisans are transforming the centuries-old cheap but elegant method of reusing offcuts.
content: For the Queens-based duo Raphael Martinez Cohen, 34, and Ryan Bush, 32, terrazzo is a way to repurpose the detritus of daily life. The two artists founded their joint sculptural practice, Ficus Interfaith, nine years ago. Since then, they have added peach stones, oyster shells, the royal blue glass of Saratoga water bottles, petrified wood and deer bones — discovered on Martinez Cohen’s parents’ property in upstate New York — to the mix of marble chips, other stone fragments and cement that is traditionally ground up to make terrazzo, the speckled composite material that has become the pair’s primary medium. Martinez Cohen and Bush combine their unconventional rock substitutes with colored cement or epoxy, forming a slurry that they pour into zinc and brass outlines to create kitschy, expressionistic tableaus. The results suggest Roman mosaics by way of Brooklyn: “Date Palm Tree (Tree of Paradise)” (2018), a 6-by-2-foot composition in a pine frame, depicts a palm tree with a wiggly trunk and faux-naïve fronds from which hang fruits inlaid with sections of real date pits.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neal E. Boudette and Brittany Greeson
title: A Spirited Start to the Strike at a Ford Plant Near Detroit
description: Union members at one of three factories chosen for a first wave of walkouts voiced determination to win substantial pay gains in their next contract.
content: Rodney Cornett got up at 4:30 a.m. on Friday, hopped in his F-150 pickup and reported as usual for a morning shift at the Ford Motor plant in Wayne, a gritty city just west of Detroit.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: NASA’s U.F.O. Chief Also an Unidentified Phenomenon
description: Quotation of the Day for Friday, September 15, 2023.
content: “One of the main goals of what we’re trying to do here today is to move conjecture and conspiracy towards science and sanity.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Marchese
title: Jann Wenner Defends His Legacy, and His Generation’s
description: The co-founder of Rolling Stone magazine on the legacy of boomers and why he chose only white men for his book on rock’s “masters.”
content: In 2019, Jann Wenner officially left Rolling Stone, the magazine he co-founded in 1967, but he hasn’t left it behind. Since stepping away from the iconic publication, where I briefly worked as an online editor a decade ago, Wenner, 77, has written two books rooted in his time there. The first, a hefty, dishy memoir called “Like a Rolling Stone,” was a best seller after it was published last year. The second, “The Masters,” which will be published on Sept. 26, consists of interviews that Wenner conducted during his Rolling Stone years with rock legends like Bob Dylan, Mick Jagger, Bono and others, as well as a new interview with Bruce Springsteen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Silverstein
title: Illegal Mopeds and Fake Names: Migrants Scrape By in Underground Economy
description: The newest migrants in New York need money but are prohibited from working. A secondary market of fake app logins and weekly bike rentals has emerged.
content: After Mayco Milano, a migrant from Venezuela, arrived in New York in late May, he spent a month walking all over Manhattan in search of work. Mr. Milano, who does not speak English, was turned down by countless restaurants. He landed a construction job, but it ended after three days, after he was asked for his Social Security number.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nate Cohn
title: Why Are Democrats Losing Ground Among Nonwhite Voters? 5 Theories.
description: There’s no shortage of solid hypotheses, and the best explanation may be a combination of them.
content: Why is President Biden losing ground among Black, Hispanic, Asian American and other nonwhite voters?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dan Charnas
title: Hip-Hop Is the Music of Vinyl Librarians
description: Hip-hop tracks became a retelling of parents’ and grandparents’ histories; each discovery of a sample source was like finding an ancestor.
content: Of all the clichés about hip-hop we’ve endured over 50 years, the idea that hip-hop is the product of the streets — with all the attendant implications about what and who is and isn’t authentic — remains the most tiresome. In reality, hip-hop is largely the product of kids who stayed inside.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Santul Nerkar and Neal E. Boudette
title: At a Detroit rally, Bernie Sanders cheers on striking workers and condemns ‘corporate greed.’
description: The senator from Vermont spoke of the growing gap between C.E.O. and worker pay, urging the leaders of the Big Three automakers to understand “the sacrifices your workers have made over the years.”
content: At a rally in downtown Detroit on Friday, just a couple of hundred yards from the headquarters of General Motors, Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont addressed a cheering crowd of United Auto Workers members, capping a day of walkouts by the union with an effort to rally support for the strike.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Billy Witz
title: His Team Was a Chaotic Punchline. Then He Found a New Spot in the Sport.
description: Dozens of players were caught up in the lies and false promises of Bishop Sycamore and Christians of Faith Academy. One player made it out to play major college football.
content: The University of Louisville football team’s fortunes are unlikely to rise and fall on the squat legs of Mario Agyen, a 5-foot-7, 190-pound, walk-on running back who joined the team in the middle of last season after an end-of-summer tryout.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Vincentelli
title: ‘Death, Let Me Do My Show’ Review: Rachel Bloom Can’t Shake the Dread
description: The writer-performer wanted to avoid the pandemic, but couldn’t. Her new solo show dives into birth, death and cosmic confusion.
content: Rachel Bloom came to perform her latest live show in New York, and she really wanted to do it as if it were 2019. That was the year when her musical-comedy series, “Crazy Ex-Girlfriend,” ended its four-season run on the CW, and Bloom was getting ready to hit the road. But in 2020, some things happened.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miya Lee
title: Love Letter: A Moment of Metamorphosis
description: Her husband promised to love her pain away. Somehow, he made the impossible, possible.
content: “I always wrote off my husband’s promises to protect me in my moments of despair because I assumed he meant he was prepared to do so physically, an engagement with masculinity that I dislike. But I had not understood his meaning.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: How to Support Ukraine Beyond the Next Election
description: Open discussion is essential to shoring up support for the country from Congress and the American public.
content: A heated and sometimes nasty debate is raging over how to end the war in Ukraine, intensified by the less-than-hoped-for advances of the Ukrainian counteroffensive and shifting American support for continuing aid to the country. A CNN survey released on Aug. 4 found that among liberals, 69 percent back more funding, but only 31 percent among conservatives do.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: The High Stakes Behind the U.A.W.’s Strike
description: The walkout by thousands of factory workers presents economic and political risks for the Big Three automakers, Midwestern states and President Biden.
content: Thousands of autoworkers walked off the job on Friday morning at three Midwest plants in an unprecedented strike, as the United Automobile Workers and Detroit’s three big carmakers remained miles apart on contract talks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Sonne
title: As Kim Inspects Russia’s Military, Putin Cultivates ‘Axis of the Sanctioned’
description: Kim Jong-un, North Korea’s leader, toured a fighter jet factory, as Russia’s president sought to cast himself as the champion of an anti-U.S. alliance in a meeting with another authoritarian.
content: North Korea’s leader, Kim Jong-un, peeked his head into the cockpit of a fighter jet at a factory in the Russian Far East on Friday as he pressed ahead on a multiday tour of Russia that is enticing him at each stop with off-limits military technology.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jordyn Holman, Jeanna Smialek and Jason Karaian
title: Will Restart of Student Loan Payments Be the Last Straw for Consumers?
description: Americans have continued spending despite dwindling savings and inflation. But retailers worry resuming loan payments could push some over the edge.
content: Mykail James has a plan for when payments on her roughly $75,000 in student loans restart next month. She’ll cut back on her “fun budget” — money reserved for travel and concerts — and she expects to limit her holiday spending.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hilary Howard
title: New York’s New Anti-Pollution Law Is Here. Even Supporters Don’t Like It.
description: Rules for Local Law 97, which curbs carbon emissions from large buildings, have come under fire as too lax or not lax enough.
content: This week, Mayor Eric Adams released proposed guidelines for Local Law 97, trailblazing climate legislation that limits fossil fuel emissions from large buildings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer
title: Special Counsel Seeking Gag Order on Trump in Election Case
description: Prosecutors have asked Judge Tanya S. Chutkan to curb statements from the former president that could intimidate witnesses, influence potential jurors or lead to harassment of others in the case.
content: Prosecutors have asked the judge overseeing former President Donald J. Trump’s federal indictment on charges of conspiring to overturn the 2020 election to impose “a narrowly tailored” gag order on him, citing his “near-daily” social media attacks on people involved in the case, according to court papers released on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: Honoring the Dockworker Killed for Defying the Mob
description: Pete Panto, who helped inspire “On the Waterfront,” finally has a tombstone in a Long Island cemetery
content: Good morning. It’s Friday. We’ll remember an often-forgotten labor organizer who helped inspire the movie “On the Waterfront.” We’ll also meet a playwright and former advertising executive who helps rabbis with their Rosh Hashana sermons.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Manohla Dargis
title: In Toronto, Films That Will Break Your Heart (and Heal It, Too)
description: The festival’s highlights ranged from Agnieszka Holland’s agonizing “Green Border,” about the migrant crisis, to Richard Linklater’s fizzy “Hit Man.”
content: “If you are on the sensitive side, please take your Kleenex out,” the Polish filmmaker Agnieszka Holland warned the audience Tuesday at the Toronto International Film Festival. Holland was trying to prepare us for her latest, “Green Border,” a great howl of a movie about the crisis at the border between Poland and Belarus. There, migrants largely from the Middle East have become pawns in what European Union officials have called a “hybrid war,” a conflict that she dramatizes with formal rigor, deep feeling and palpably restrained outrage.
source.name: The New York Times

title: An Essential Mitski Primer
description: The singer-songwriter’s seventh album, “The Land Is Inhospitable and So Are We,” is out Friday.
content: The singer-songwriter Mitski first caught my ear in 2014, when she released the sharply penned and tunefully guitar-driven album “Bury Me at Makeout Creek.” (It’s a “Simpsons” reference.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Styles Desk
title: Everything to Know About Fashion Week (So Far)
description: The weirdest, wildest and most wearable moments from the spring 2024 shows.
content: Fashion month — or the back-to-back fashion weeks in New York, London, Milan and Paris — is underway once again. Hundreds of shows will take place before it ends, not to mention dozens of parties. And for every look shown on the runways, there will be others worth noticing on the streets outside the spring 2024 shows.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: Lessons Learned From the Print Hub
description: After a few months writing (and rewriting) headlines for the front page of The New York Times, one journalist has some takeaways.
content: It was my first night working as an editor on the Print Hub, the team of New York Times planners, editors and designers who produce the daily print newspaper, and my first thought was: Is the job really so … easy?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Callie Holtermann and Frank Rojas
title: Are Men Obsessed With the Roman Empire? Yes, Say Men.
description: Women are asking the men in their lives how often they think about ancient Rome. Their responses, posted online, can be startling in their frequency.
content: The Roman Empire began in 27 B.C. and fell in A.D. 476.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gaia Pianigiani
title: An Italian Island Reflects Giorgia Meloni’s Challenges on Migration
description: The prime minister is facing increased pressure from her right-wing coalition partners as the number of migrants trying to enter the country via Lampedusa soars.
content: On Italy’s southernmost island, Lampedusa, thousands of migrants crowded a reception center built for 600, as small boats hailing from Tunisia kept arriving. Outside Rome, a bus carrying migrants en route from Sicily to a center in the north crashed into a truck on Friday, killing the drivers of both vehicles and injuring 19 migrants.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kayla Guo
title: At the Capitol, Even the Attending Physician Can’t Escape Politics
description: Dr. Brian P. Monahan has been thrust into the center of a political controversy as Senator Mitch McConnell, the minority leader, seeks to dismiss concerns about his age and health.
content: When Senator Mitch McConnell of Kentucky, 81, wanted to quiet concerns about his health after two alarming on-camera episodes in which he appeared unable to speak or move, he turned to Dr. Brian P. Monahan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alida Becker
title: Dwelling in the Past, in the Literary Sense
description: From the dark heart of a misguided follower to the young hand of a diarist whose words outlived her, these novels encompass the full spectrum of humanity.
content: “Maybe visiting a site of memory, even if the memories are other people’s, is a way of giving history a chance to settle.” This is just one of the explanations the Flemish writer Stefan Hertmans gives for his activities in THE ASCENT (Pantheon, illustrated, 384 pp., $30), his most recent pastiche of fiction, memoir and Sebaldian evidence gathering. Inspired by the discovery that his former home in Ghent once housed a notorious Nazi collaborator, Hertmans deftly blends reporting and speculation as he reimagines the lives these rooms once sheltered, laying out the terrible consequences of an ambitious man’s blinkered devotion to the bureaucracy of the Reich.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas L. Friedman
title: A Trip to Ukraine Clarified the Stakes. And They’re Huge.
description: Ukraine is a game-changer for the West, rivaling the importance of German unification, and the European Union is the key.
content: While visiting Kyiv last week, my first trip to Ukraine since Vladimir Putin’s invasion in February 2022, I tried to get my exercise every morning by walking the grounds of St. Michael’s Golden Domed Monastery. Its serenity, though, has been disrupted by a jarring exhibit of destroyed Russian tanks and armored personnel carriers. During my walks, I’d poke my head into these jagged, rocket-pierced hulks, wondering what terrible death must have come to the Russian soldiers operating them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear
title: Biden Defends Striking Autoworkers: They Deserve a ‘Fair Share’
description: White House aides believe the battle between the car companies and their workers underscores many of the president’s policy positions.
content: President Biden forcefully sided with the striking United Auto Workers on Friday, dispatching two of his top aides to Detroit and calling for the three biggest American car companies to share their profits with employees whose wages and benefits he said have been unfairly eroded for years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Grace Lee
title: A Match Made in the Cardiologist’s Office
description: Harvey Goldberg and Freda Levenson were set up by Ms. Levenson’s cousin, giving them a chance at love after loss.
content: One day in June 2019, when Cecile Gray Bazelon went to see her cardiologist, she had matters of the heart on her mind. But she wasn’t focused on the physical heart, exactly. She wanted to set up her cousin Freda June Levenson with the doctor, Harvey Lee Goldberg.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Debra Kamin
title: The Latest Cool Amenity? A Name Brand. How About Porsche?
description: The market for branded luxury condos is growing, and now includes fashion houses and luxury carmakers, especially in Miami. In some buildings, a car elevator will lift you to your own parking spot.
content: Chart a 10-mile path down the Miami coast, and the options for luxury shopping are endless. But from Fendi to Missoni to Porsche to Bentley, the branded products many shoppers are buying aren’t items you can take home. They are homes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stanley Reed
title: Britain and Tata Agree to $1.6 Billion Package for Steel Mill
description: The plan aims to cut both emissions and financial losses at Britain’s largest steel mill, but a union says it will also put many jobs at risk.
content: The British government and Tata Steel on Friday announced a 1.25-billion-pound package, or about $1.6 billion, to cut emissions and financial losses at Tata’s steel mill — the country’s largest — at Port Talbot in Wales, potentially putting many of the plant’s 4,000 jobs at risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Wonking Out: Time, Memory and Inflation
description: One reason voters don’t see the good news (yet).
content: Almost all the available evidence suggests that the U.S. economy is achieving what many economists had thought impossible — a soft landing in which inflation returns to acceptable levels without a recession. Yet polls suggest that the public remains very down on the state of the economy. Why?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elena Sheppard
title: Audiobook of the Week: ‘Poems of the Night,’ by Jorge Luis Borges
description: Read in both English and Spanish by Juanita Devis, the Argentine writer’s verses trace his descent into blindness.
content: Jorge Luis Borges might be best known for his fiction, but it can’t be forgotten that the 20th-century literary giant was also an eminent Latin American poet. First published in hardcover in 2010, “Poems of the Night” is a career-spanning collection of more than 50 of Borges’s poems, presented in the original Spanish alongside English translations. Now that it’s available in audiobook form, bilingual listeners can compare and contrast the experiences of hearing the poems in each language, revealing the delicate and detailed work of celebrated translators like W. S. Merwin and Alan S. Trueblood.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Pareles, Giovanni Russonello and Lindsay Zoladz
title: Maren Morris Revels in a Fresh Start, and 10 More New Songs
description: Hear tracks by Cat Power, Chris Stapleton, Loraine James and others.
content: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new tracks. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage, and The Amplifier, a twice-weekly guide to new and old songs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aaron Boxerman
title: Access to Derna Is Limited as Libyan Authorities Struggle in Flood’s Aftermath
description: Thousands remain missing following the devastating flood in the country’s northeast. Health officials fear the window to recover them alive is closing.
content: The Libyan authorities curbed access to much of the northeastern city of Derna on Friday, as health officials and relief crews struggled to handle thousands of victims of the floods that have devastated the region.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Will Heinrich
title: Tadaaki Kuwayama, Painter of Cool but Vivid Monochromes, Dies at 91
description: Arriving in New York from Japan in 1958, he sought to “create works with no trace of touch.”
content: Tadaaki Kuwayama, a celebrated painter who forged a distinctively minimal path with cool but vividly colored monochromes and diptychs, died on Aug. 18 in Manhattan. He was 91.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Schuessler
title: A New Home for Brooklyn History: ‘Everybody’s Story Is Here’
description: The Center for Brooklyn History, formerly known as the Brooklyn Historical Society, reopens after a three-year renovation, with free admission and an emphasis on outreach.
content: Ask a Brooklynite to define New York’s most populous borough, and you’ll get 2.7 million answers — or more. At the renovated and rebranded Center for Brooklyn History, they’re going with an ellipsis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sindya N. Bhanoo
title: In Three New Story Collections, Much Is Left Unsaid
description: Speaking across linguistic and emotional boundaries, or perhaps not speaking at all, these characters leave the reader to read between the lines.
content: Reading each tale in Diane Williams’s I HEAR YOU’RE RICH: Stories (Soho Press, 111 pp., $20) feels like looking into the deep, expressive eyes of a person who doesn’t speak much: A great deal is left unsaid. Many of the stories, only two to four pages long, cast light on seemingly ordinary moments in the lives of women quietly struggling against forces that are not always clear to them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Mayoral Candidate Who Faces Jan. 6 Charges Wins Primary Recount
description: Gino DiGiovanni Jr., who was charged with trespassing at the U.S. Capitol, is the Republican nominee for mayor in a small Connecticut city that voted for President Biden.
content: Republican voters in Derby, Conn., have rejected the city’s three-term incumbent mayor in favor of a man who was charged with trespassing during the Jan. 6 Capitol riot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Ewing
title: U.A.W. Starts Strike Small, but Repercussions Could Prove Far-Reaching
description: The union targeted three factories: one run by General Motors, one by Ford and one by Stellantis. Prolonged walkouts could hurt the U.S. economy and President Biden.
content: Autoworkers walked off the job on Friday at three factories that produce some of the Detroit carmakers’ most popular vehicles, the opening salvos in what could become a protracted strike that hurts the U.S. economy and has an impact on the 2024 presidential election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sean T. Collins
title: ‘Billions’ Season 7, Episode 6 Recap: From Russia With Love
description: The insurrectionists at Prince Cap aren’t doing a great job of slowing Mike down. But Chuck might just have a new redheaded ace up his sleeve.
content: “The irresistible force meets the immovable object.” This quote should be familiar to Chuck Rhoades. As this week’s episode of “Billions” goes to great lengths to point out, Chuck is fan of professional wrestling. He would no doubt recall the wrestling commentator Gorilla Monsoon excitedly describing the clash between Hulk Hogan and his friend turned nemesis Andre the Giant at WrestleMania III with these exact words. Indeed, Chuck’s erstwhile ally, the Russian oligarch Grigor Andolov (John Malkovich), references the match by name during this very episode.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rosalie R. Radomsky
title: All Systems Go After a Relationship Check-In
description: Every month, Millie Tran and Brian Rosenthal sit down for a relationship check-in to go over chores, finances and other matters. During one check-in, marriage plans took off.
content: In July 2020, after a mutual friend told Brian Martin Rosenthal that Millie Minh-Diep Tran was single and in New York, he took a chance and reached out to her on Twitter. When that chat fizzled out, he tried again on Instagram, with more success.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Williams
title: Bobby Schiffman, Guiding Force of the Apollo Theater, Dies at 94
description: Taking over for his father in 1961, he transformed a former vaudeville house in Harlem into a pre-eminent R&B showcase.
content: Bobby Schiffman, who guided the Apollo Theater in Harlem through the seismic cultural and musical changes of the 1960s and early ’70s, cementing its place as a world-renowned showcase for Black music and entertainment, died on Sept. 6 at his home in Boynton Beach, Fla. He was 94.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tammy LaGorce and Kyna Uwaeme
title: For Disabled Couples, a Plea for Marriage Equality
description: Twenty couples gathered in Washington to show their commitment to each other and the fight against laws that make it financially difficult for people with disabilities to marry.
content: On Wednesday afternoon, 20 couples gathered in front of a stage at the National Mall in Washington to recite their commitment vows. Some brides had on white gowns while grooms wore top hats. Others donned orange T-shirts printed with the words “Disability Rights Are Human Rights.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rob Copeland
title: Billionaire Ray Dalio Pushes for Return to Hedge Fund in Succession Clash
description: Mr. Dalio retired from Bridgewater last year. But his successors at the world’s biggest hedge fund are discovering it’s not easy to operate with the firm’s founder looming over them.
content: Less than a year after retiring, Ray Dalio, the founder of Bridgewater Associates, the world’s largest hedge fund, is threatening his former colleagues with the one thing they have worked hard to prevent: his return.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Stanford
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mitch Smith
title: Jury Acquits 3 Men Accused of Aiding Plot to Kidnap Michigan’s Governor
description: The trial was the final chapter in a sprawling case involving Gov. Gretchen Whitmer. Others have been convicted in the kidnap plot.
content: Jurors in northern Michigan acquitted three men on Friday who were accused of providing support to a plot to kidnap the state’s Democratic governor, Gretchen Whitmer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater
title: Witness Testimony Casts Doubt on Some Biden Impeachment Allegations
description: As Republicans announced they were moving forward with an impeachment inquiry, fresh evidence emerged this week casting doubt on some of the key claims.
content: As Republicans plunge forward with an impeachment inquiry looking into a complex web of allegations against President Biden, his family and his administration, witnesses they have summoned for closed-door interviews in recent weeks have undercut or pushed back against some of their major claims.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elian Peltier
title: As Junta Tightens Grip, Niger Is Being Strangled by Sanctions
description: Border closures and a freeze on financial transactions imposed after soldiers seized power are hurting millions, while Western nations remain divided over what to do.
content: Since a military coup in Niger this summer, work days for Ahmed Alhousseïni have been consumed with calls from increasingly worried clients and colleagues asking the same questions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse
title: Facing a Shutdown, Congress Melts Down
description: Bands of Republicans in the House and the Senate have brought the spending debate to a screeching halt with a shutdown just days away.
content: Bringing some order to Capitol Hill is proving to be an extraordinarily tall order.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Keith Bradsher
title: China’s Slumping Economy: What the Latest Numbers Are Signaling
description: Consumers are spending a little more, but apartment prices and the pace of construction keep falling.
content: China’s trains, planes, stores and beaches were a little fuller last month than a year earlier, and the pace of activity picked up at factories, particularly those making mobile phones and semiconductors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: Drew Barrymore Doubles Down on Show’s Return: ‘This Is Bigger Than Me’
description: In a since-deleted video, Barrymore responded to continuing criticism after her decision to bring back her talk show amid the Hollywood writers’ strike.
content: Drew Barrymore is not the only talk show host returning to air amid ongoing strikes by Hollywood writers and actors, but in the span of a week she has become perhaps the most high-profile target for criticism over the decision.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gyal Lo
title: The One Million Tibetan Children in China’s Boarding Schools
description: China’s vast network of boarding schools in Tibet is separating families and threatening Tibetan culture.
content: One day in late November 2016, back home in Tibet, I received a distressing call from my brother telling me I needed to check on his granddaughters. “Something very strange is happening,” he said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Hauser
title: Bob Boilen, of NPR, to Push Back From His Tiny Desk
description: Mr. Boilen, a co-creator of the Tiny Desk concert series and other programs, is retiring in October.
content: Bob Boilen, who created, hosted and directed “All Things Considered” and “All Songs Considered” and became one of the premier tastemakers in American music with the Tiny Desk concert series, said he would be retiring from NPR after 35 years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Taub
title: What I’m Reading: Eclectic Edition
description: The fruits of a free-ranging reading week were a fascinating book on China and a political science paper that explains a quirk of far-right politics.
content: Some weeks, as I try to chase down a particular idea or understand a particular event, my reading lists have clear themes: what to read to understand X; three books on Y.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Proulx
title: Are You a Joiner?
description: Are you often the first to sign up for a new group, club or team? Or are you skeptical of organized activities?
content: There’s a new club at school dedicated to an activity you love: say, anime, Fortnite, knitting or community service. Do you join? Why, or why not? What, if anything, would get you to sign up?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Michael McGrath, Tony Winner and ‘Spamalot’ Veteran, Dies at 65
description: He clanged coconuts in the Monty Python stage musical in 2005; seven years later, he won a Tony for “Nice Work if You Can Get It.”
content: Michael McGrath, who won a Tony Award in 2012 for his work in the musical “Nice Work if You Can Get It” and was a regular on Broadway, Off Broadway and regional stages, known especially for comedic roles and for his ability to conjure the likes of Groucho Marx, George M. Cohan and Jackie Gleason, died on Thursday at his home in Bloomfield, N.J. He was 65.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sapna Maheshwari and Emma Goldberg
title: TikTok Rankles Employees With Return-to-Office Tracking Tools
description: The company is requiring many employees to use an app that tracks their in-person attendance.
content: TikTok employees in the United States expressed frustration and dismay this week after the company introduced a tool for tracking office attendance and threatened disciplinary action for failing to comply with new in-person mandates, in an unusual effort to get workers back into the office with custom data-collection technology.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Erlanger
title: European Countries to Keep Some Missile Sanctions on Iran
description: U.N. sanctions are set to expire in October, as part of the 2015 nuclear deal. Other nations, including Russia, will be free to buy Iranian missiles and drones.
content: In a gesture of frustration with Iran’s flagrant breach of its commitments to limit nuclear enrichment under the 2015 Iran nuclear deal, Britain, France and Germany have said they would retain ballistic missile and nuclear proliferation-related sanctions on Iran that were set to expire in mid-October.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: In the Autoworkers’ Strike, One Side Has the Higher Ground
description: The United Auto Workers have leverage and a solid case that’s likely to win them public favor.
content: Members of the United Auto Workers union have a strong hand in their strike against General Motors, Ford Motor and Stellantis. Their negotiators have reason to believe that they should come close to getting what they’re asking for, which includes raises of 40 percent over four years. I don’t foresee the autoworkers caving. If the automakers also refuse to cave, this strike could drag on, harming both parties to the conflict as well as the general public. That would be unfortunate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jerrine Tan
title: Pinned Under the Bodies of Men
description: I thought being sexually bold was a game I was allowed to play. I had no idea of the punishment that awaited me — or the surprising healing to come.
content: I have been pinned under the body of a man more than once.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Cottle, Ross Douthat, Carlos Lozada and Lydia Polgreen
title: ‘A Red State Strategy to Create a Blue State Crisis’
description: The ‘border crisis’ has left the border — the political response has been chaotic.
content: Hundreds of thousands of migrants, many seeking asylum, have arrived in the United States over the last year, overwhelming already-strained resources in cities and states across the country. Last week, in arguably one of the most immigration-friendly cities in the country, Mayor Eric Adams said that migrants would “destroy New York City.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: Mitt Romney Has It Half Right
description: Republicans are adept at twisting the Constitution.
content: “A very large portion of my party,” Senator Mitt Romney of Utah tells McKay Coppins of The Atlantic, “really doesn’t believe in the Constitution.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Previewing a Spring of Culture in Australia
description: Offerings in art, culture, design, music and theater across the country.
content: Balmy temperatures have set in across much of Australia. It won’t last — the forecast is back to cooler weather early next week — but the dose of warmth is a good reminder that summer, with its plethora of cultural attractions, is not too far away.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andy Newman
title: House Democrats Visit a Migrant Hotel as Political Tensions Erupt
description: After New York City’s mayor begged for help from the federal government, Congressional Democrats, including Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, came to visit the city’s main migrant shelter.
content: For months, as New York City staggered under the impact of more than 110,000 asylum seekers from the southern border, Mayor Eric Adams has pleaded for help from the federal government.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer and Charlie Savage
title: Special Counsel Obtained 32 Private Messages From Trump’s Twitter Account
description: Newly unsealed court papers shed additional light on a legal fight whose existence was revealed last month.
content: The federal prosecutors who charged former President Donald J. Trump with a criminal conspiracy over his attempts to overturn the 2020 election obtained 32 private messages from his Twitter account through a search warrant this winter as part of their investigation, court papers unsealed on Friday said.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Republican Attempt to Impeach President Biden
description: Explaining the timing and rationale of the third formal attempt by Congress to remove a president in the past four years.
content: Speaker Kevin McCarthy has ordered an impeachment inquiry into President Biden, putting into motion the third formal attempt by Congress to remove a president in the past four years.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Today’s Top News: A Scramble for Rescuers in Libya, and More
description: Exclusively from New York Times Audio, our new app.
content: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.
