title: London’s Buzziest Young Designer Is Sitting Out Fashion Week
description: Dilara Findikoglu has dressed Margot Robbie and Cardi B and has been embraced by the fashion industry. Why would she cancel her runway show at the last minute?
content: Dilara Findikoglu had the kind of summer most emerging designers could only dream of.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Sept. 15, 2023
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Friday, Sept. 15, 2023.
content: Because of an editing error, a picture caption with an article on Tuesday about fire spotters in Montana misidentified the location of the Flathead Hot Shot Crew. The crew is based out of the Flathead National Forest, near — not in — Glacier National Park.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kwame Anthony Appiah
title: Our Daughter Makes Money Acting. Should We Save the Same Amount for Her Twin?
description: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on how to fairly parent children with different abilities.
content: We have 8-year-old twins, I. and J. They have lots of interests and are bright, interesting young people. J. recently became a professional actor; she even appeared in a national commercial. We gave her $100 of the $800 she was paid for the ad, and as you would expect, she spent it on roller skating, treats and toys. The rest of the money was put into her college fund. I. is on the autism spectrum, which for numerous reasons makes equivalencies between the two children difficult (for example, acting is out of the question for I. right now, but college is definitely feasible).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farhad Manjoo
title: I Finally Learned How to Draw. Here’s How.
description: Computers have done for drawing and painting what word processors once did for writing.
content: For as long as I can remember, I’ve wanted to learn to draw. And for as long I can remember, I’ve been failing to learn to draw. I just couldn’t get the hang of it; every time I put pencil to paper, it ended in frustration, and repeated frustration inevitably calcified into defeat. Though I’ve never really stopped trying — my junk closet brims with abandoned art supplies — at some point I internalized my failure. A lot of drawing teachers say that everyone can learn to draw. A lot of drawing teachers haven’t met me, I thought. I was an exception. Even Pictionary filled me with anxiety.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin
title: Her Father Is the B.T.K. Killer. She’s Helping to Close More Cases.
description: Dennis Rader terrorized Kansas for decades before his arrest in 2005. His daughter, Kerri Rawson, could not bear to see him until this June, when she visited him in prison to help investigators.
content: Kerri Rawson sees her life in two parts: before and after she learned that her father was a serial killer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush
title: The Gun Charges Against Hunter Biden Are Unusual. Here’s Why.
description: The heart of the federal case against the president’s son — that he lied about drug use on a federal form when he purchased a handgun — is not typically the basis for a stand-alone prosecution.
content: On the face of it, Hunter Biden appears at risk of being sentenced to as long as 25 years in prison and $750,000 in fines if he is convicted on the three gun charges brought against him by federal prosecutors on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: After Brutal Attacks and Fierce Debate, U.K. to Ban ‘American Bully XL’ Dogs
description: Prime Minister Rishi Sunak announced steps to outlaw the dogs on Friday, after a string of deaths and a social media campaign piled pressure on the government to act.
content: The video, shot from a passing bus and lasting barely a minute, is harrowing. A powerful young dog bites an 11-year-old girl in front of a grocery store in Birmingham, England. As pedestrians scatter in terror, the dog chases a man into a gas station plaza, pulling him down repeatedly, its jaws clamped on the man’s arm and shoulder, as he tries desperately to shake off the animal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Gardner
title: The Unlikely Rise of an American Team in a Sport You’ve Never Heard Of
description: Sepak takraw, sometimes called “kick volleyball,” is enormously popular in swaths of Southeast Asia. An unlikely advocate of the sport has built a takraw dynasty in the United States.
content: When Ker Cha got the call about the World Cup, it had been more than two years since he had touched a takraw ball. Now he had less than two months to lose the 20 pounds he had put on during the coronavirus pandemic and get back into playing shape. Plus, he learned he would have only two days to train with his teammates before they took off for the 2022 International Sepak Takraw Federation World Cup in South Korea.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: Iowa Teen Found Guilty of Fatally Shooting 2 Students
description: In January, Preston Walls fatally shot a 16-year-old and an 18-year-old who were part of an educational program for at-risk youths.
content: An Iowa teenager was found guilty on Thursday of second-degree murder and manslaughter in the shooting deaths of two students in January at an educational program for at-risk youths.
